lines.text: Don't spit on my cupcake and tell me it's frosting.
Who are you?
I'm here for pain and suffering.
Yours or mine?
Don't pee on my leg and tell me it's raining.
I'm speaking. When my mouth moves, yours stops.
Beauty fades. Dumb is forever.
Do you come from a long line of idiots?
You know how I can tell if a 17-year-old girl is lying? When her mouth moves.
...I would trust your witness much more if he didn't have holes in his jeans.
...Take your hands off your hips and stand up straight, like you're in court... Uncross your arms. You are not at the beach... Hey, stop swaying! It's making me nauseous.
Baloney!
I don't care how the Word of God applies here. This is a courtroom, not a church, so don't preach to me.
If it doesn't make sense, it's not true.

These children are entitled to at least one parent to set a good example. Grownups take care of their children, they don't just provide them with food, they provide them with a moral compass. They try not to teach them to become brawling animals in parking lots, hitting each other with 2X4's, scratching each others' eyes out. Human beings don't do that to each other. You don't belong at a club at 12 a.m., you belong HOME! Reading them stories from a BOOK!

[to a litigant who waved for her attention]
... Believe me, you are NOT that eager for me to embarrass you.
You, sir, are a low-life, amoral piece of crap!
When you can't look at me in the eye and tell me the story, that means you're lying.
You have to speak slowly and PROJECT what you are saying!

[to a male litigant, who's been pitted against a female litigant]
... Personally, I don't find you as attractive as she did; so I suggest you *shut up*!
I'm sorry, I'm very nervous.
Well - get un-nervous.
Do you have a job? Well, GET ONE!
...I am not going to ask you to leave. But, the next time you come into my courtroom, dress more appropriately. You are not going to a beach party.
Umm is not an answer.
If you live to be a hundred, you will never be as smart as me. On your BEST day, you're not as smart as *I* am on my WORST day.
I'm the boss, Applesauce.
Is the word stupid written across my forehead?
He signed me a promissory note...
I don't care if he signed you the Declaration of Independence!
This is my courtroom and I can say what I want. When you become a judge, we will talk.
Just a second!
...You are not a good witness. Because a good witness answers a Judge's question directly, and my question to you was a very simple one. A SIX YEAR OLD COULD ANSWER IT!

[about a girl wearing too-skimpy attire]
... Byrd, get her a jumper; she looks cold!
I don't want you, or anybody else, to think I'm stupid. Old, maybe; stupid, never.

You're gonna keep your mouth shut until I come to you and ask you a question; otherwise, Byrd will take you outside until you understand the rules. Because here, I'm in charge... I run this show. Do you understand? You don't speak until I speak to you. Or do you want me to label you a liar before we even begin?
...I eat morons like you for breakfast. You're gonna be crying before this is over.
The only attitude I tolerate around here is my own! You speak, then I rule, and after that you shut up. Do you understand?
it's dismissed. You should bless her, not sue her!
Touch every third person, and you'll find an idiot.
Women do stupid things when they're in love. That's why I've been in business for twelve years.
For what I'd like to say right now, I wish we were on cable... I'm not gonna waste another second on this case. Between the two of you, I doubt I could put together a three-digit IQ.
I only do one thing at a time; otherwise, I get confused and then I can't trick you.
I love the truth. If you don't tell me the truth, you're gonna be eating your shoes.
Don't get too comfortable. This case is not going to take long.
Your counterclaim for your stress is dismissed. That's because the only one who is stressed around here, so far, is me.
There's only one wise-ass I tolerate in my courtroom... and that's the bailiff.
There are all kinds of worthwhile charities around. Breast augmentation surgery doesn't fall into that category.

...That's why they don't let people drink until they're 21 years old, because even 21-year-olds are morons. 20-year-olds and 19-year-olds are double-morons. They shouldn't even be allowed out of the house after nine o'clock at night.
it interferes with Sundays; and the players don't run around bases.

What do I know about Myspace? It's an Internet site where people, who have nothing better to do with their time, go and chat about a whole bunch of nonsense. We could eliminate a third of the problems in this country, if people actually had to shovel coal into a furnace for heat... rather than spending all that time they have making problems for other people, by sitting at their personal computers doing things other than those which PCs were actually designed for.
...So you didn't feel the need to file taxes last year, huh? That's very interesting; I'll make sure the IRS receives a copy of this tape.

[mimicking a litigant]
"... She ran out of my house and slammed the door, breaking a window. I was extremely upset, so I grabbed a rock and tossed it gently at her car."
...I have a lot to be proud of.
Like what?
I graduated high school.
Oh, well! That's, like, the Eighth Wonder of the World, isn't it!
Yes - By our family's standards, that's a great accomplishment.

[to a litigant]
You mess around with me, and I'll wipe the floor with you. Do we follow each other?
You don't seem to get the drill here in court. In a court, I ask the questions and you answer the questions. So far, you've answered the questions and you've gotten most of them wrong.

People who are single and living together shouldn't rent for a higher monthly rate than either of them could pay alone. Now I know I'm probably going to lose about 40% of my cases if I say this, but I'm willing to make that sacrifice for the common good. If only enough folks got that through their heads! Then you wouldn't have two people who are homeless, with their credit in the toilet. THEN they could part ways without all that fuss and aggravation!
NEVER cosign on anybody's behalf for anything, and I mean NOT EVER!
[to the plaintiff]
Having said that, I think you should have brought your case to me sooner.

[to a plaintiff]
... My own children have taken my cars and had accidents. Once, one of my sons went over an embankment into a ditch; then he told me that the earth opened up because of severe rain, that such was how the car slid down the roadside. Needless to say, that story didn't work; but I didn't SUE him, either.

[Describing an altercation with a traffic cop]
He wasn't listening to what I had to say...
He doesn't have to listen to you! If you want someone to listen to you, you should go to a psychiatrist!
Don't try to teach a pig to sing. It doesn't work and it annoys the pig.
Instead of going to the police, why didn't she take the couch and television and put in on a truck and take it to his house?
I will tell you why
Why?
It is too big, you can't even get it out of the door of the condo... the couch and the television.
Madam, did they build the condo around the couch and the television?
What's next? You can only be evicted when you pay rent.
Pain and suffering
I'm in pain.
I'm in pain too.
Did I come to you? Then don't come to me.
You say he harasses you, he says you harass him, you know who is really harassed here? Me!

[yelling]
I don't believe you!
I don't care what you think! *I'm* the one who has to determine what is fair.
...And you ought to be ashamed of yourself!
"Some Other Dude Done It."
...Yeah, right, and I was born in 1965.
Have you ever heard of the K.I.S.S. principle? "Keep It Simple, Stupid."
This is not "Let's Make a Deal," and I'm not Monty Hall!
When you mess around with jail-bait, you accept the consequences!
I'm here because I'm smart, not because I'm young and gorgeous... although I am!
...Do you feel as if you're getting whipped?
[laughs]
You sure are!
...You spent $72 getting your hair done? You wasted your money!
...Two people can't talk at the same time. When my mouth is moving, it means that you need to be quiet.
Do you know when a gift becomes a loan? When the relationship is over. Have you ever heard that, sir? Well, neither have I. I just made it up. I'm going to put it on coffee mugs.
...Sir, the *table* didn't have three beers and then get up and move!
...Of course I'm right; I'm always right. I'm like a truth machine.
...This is your aggravation. Not his. He doesn't want your aggravation. Byrd doesn't want your aggravation...
[to the bailiff]
... Do you, Byrd?
I have 3 sons, so I know you are no gift! You're not even good looking!
How old are you?
Parties have been sworn in, Judge.
[to audience]
You may be seated.

[the end of many cases]
Goodbye, have a happy life!

[pointing to two feuding exes]
This genius picked this genius!
What school of double-talk did you go to?
...Ridiculous. NEXT!
DON'T lie to me!
Hey! QUIET!
[repeated line]
...You are to respond, "Yes, ma'am"!
Don't look up at the heavens. God is not going to help you with this case. Only the truth will set you free.
If you want the facts, you go to a therapist. If you want the law, you come to court.
In court, I ask the questions; you answer them. And so far, you've gotten most of them wrong.
Don't let the word "bar" fool you. This is a courtroom, not a barroom.
...You're lying. I can tell because the hairs on the back of my neck are standing up.
You say you're on disability for a bad back? Couldn't you get a job in an office or something?
Everyone is equal in the eyes of the law, but that doesn't mean the law has to treat everyone equally.
The sexes are not equal. They only start out equal, and then something happens along the way... You think it's sports? Contact sports, maybe, to the head.
Sir, do you wanna say something to me? Are you sure you wanna say something to me...? No, you don't. Believe me, that is the LAST thing you want.
[Judge Judy states her opinion of people who have themselves excessively tattooed]

Yeah, well, I'm probably just very old-fashioned about this whole tattoo thing. I think that when people do that in excess, which clearly to me, there's, there are excesses. I would prefer that somebody say, "Look at me, look at me, this is what I've accomplished. I wrote a book. I graduated from college. I've just completed a wonderful work of art that I hung in a museum. Something that I've accomplished," rather than saying, "Look at me, look at me, I'm gonna be the most outlandish I can be so I can get your attention." There's positive attention, there's negative attention. But maybe there will come a point where being tattooed over your whole body is accepted. I will be long gone when that happens fortunately!

[repeated voice over]
Real cases, real people. Judge Judy.

[theme music with voice over introduction]
You are about to enter the courtroom of Judge Judith Sheindlin. The people are real, the cases are real, the rulings are final. This is Judge Judy.
The police said get in by any means necessary.
I don't believe it! That never happens!
Oh, please!
I got an A for Torts in Law School.
Did you forget you were coming to court today?
...I think you ought to be quiet. You know, they don't need anybody stirring up the pot. You're a pot-stirrer.
This birthday is going to be more expensive than you thought!
...That's going to be the most expensive curse word you ever said!
...Did you just curse at him? Get out!

[to the defendant who denies owing the plaintiff any money]
Let me explain something to you, my husband once offended me on July 6th 1978. I can tell you exactly where I was sitting, and what he was eating. Most people have a memory of important dates and times. Now if somebody, gave me/loaned to be $5000 I would remember some of the circumstances surrounding it - because you, sir seem to have a very, very good memory of everything you did - calling the bank, calling the title company, getting the checks, sitting down and going over everything - the only thing you don't have a memory of is "Can I borrow $5000?". Judgment to the plaintiff for the amount of $5000 - thank you.
...I think something's wrong.

[yelling]
You get it?
Stop getting hysterical.
Never combine business with pleasure; that's not good business. Got what I mean?
Are you on any medication?
Get over it!
What do you do for a living, Sir?
Um...
"Um" is not an answer! What kind of training did you need to do "Um"?
So far this case is going in your favor, madam; does it look like I need any help?... THEN SHUT UP!

[Judy is tearing up some love letters the Defendant recieved from the Defendent]
Can I suggest something Ma'am?

[looks up from tearing the letters]
Shhh!
[continues tearing them up]
